description: From corruption of French louis, from Louis, presumably Louis IX or Louis XI, who issued gold écus.

nouns.description: lew (plural lews or lewis or leois)

entries.meaning: (Scotland, obsolete) A French gold coin circulated in 15th-century Scotland.
examples: ...þe Ingliss noble, henry, ande Eduarde wt þe ross, þe franche crowne, þe salute þe lewe and þe Ridar sall haif courss in þis realme...

description: From Middle English lew, lewe, from Old English hlēow, hlēowe (“warm, sunny, sheltered”), from Proto-Germanic *hlewaz, *hliwjaz, *hlēwaz (“warm, lukewarm”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱal(w)e-, *ḱlēw- (“warm, hot”). Cognate with Old Norse hlýr (“warm, mild”), ( > Danish ly (“lukewarm”)), hlær, German lau, which are themselves akin to Old Norse hlé (“lee”), Danish læ (“shelter”). Compare lee.

examples: Lee or Lew, Calm, under the wind. Suss.
To th' end a fruitfull lewMay euerie Climate in his time renew.

entries.meaning: (dialect) A shelter from the wind, particularly temporary structures raised by shepherds to protect their flocks.
examples: Lew, shelter; defence from storms or wind.

verbs.description: lew (third-person singular simple present lews, present participle lewing, simple past and past participle lewed)

examples: Lew... Those trees will lew the house when they're up-grown.

description: Uncertain, but compare Old English ġelewed (“weakness, infirmity”) and limlǣweo (“limb-weak, lame”). Possibly related to Proto-Germanic *laiwą (“damage”); compare Old Norse læ (“venom, bane”).

adjectives.description: lew (comparative more lew, superlative most lew)

verbs.description: lew (third-person singular simple present lews, present participle lewing, simple past and past participle lewed)

entries.meaning: (mining, dialect, transitive) Alternative form of lue: to sift, particularly while mining tin or silver.
examples: Cornwall... The fine [sc. tin] is lewed in a fine sierce.
